I am not impressed with Phil Leigh's analysis of Grant's generalship.

Leigh skips over Grant's capture of Fort Henry and Fort Donelson. He ignores Grant's reason for being in the vicinity of Shiloh. He fails to mention how Grant came to put his army in front of Vicksburg. He neglected to discuss how Grant reached Chattanooga with men and badly needed supplies; it's true Grant never ordered Thomas's men to capture the heights of Missionary Ridge, but it's also true that he had nothing but praise for their courage and initiative.

Everyone agreed at the time and ever since that Cold Harbor was a bloody mistake. There were others in the encirclement of Richmond. The commanding general is always ultimately responsible, but Phil Leigh would have us believe that Grant was solely responsible for every failure of planning or execution.

Bush v Gore was a bad decision when it was issued, although it did say something useful, that states had to treat each voter equally.  What is really shameful is that since Bush v Gore came out in 2000, the US Supreme Court has been confronted with dozens of lower court rulings in which the lower court upheld disparate treatment of voters.  And never has the US Supreme Court chosen to take one of those cases and apply the same good principle.  Just two months ago, the US Supreme Court refused to hear Libertarian Party v D.C. Board of Elections.  The lower court had said that the D.C. has no obligation to count the valid votes cast for Libertarian presidential nominee Bob Barr, and the US Supreme Court didn't even ask for a response, much less take the case.

Actually, if the Florida electoral votes had been thrown out [even assuming that this was possible] and awarded to neither candidate, then Gore would have won.  The Constitution awards the presidency to the candidate who gets a majority of the electoral votes actually cast; it does not require a candidate to get a majority of all electoral votes, cast or not.  Without Florida in the mix, Gore had more electoral votes than Bush, and that would have been enough.  By the same token, the Constitution specifically gives each state the right to choose its electors by whatever manner they wish.  Therefore, it was up to the Fla. legislature, or its Supreme Court, to make the ultimate decision on who, if anyone, got the states electoral votes.  If SCOTUS had actually read the Constitution instead of deciding to elect its preferred candidate, it would have declined to take Bush vs. Gore for lack of jurisdiction and let the state decide.  The fact that the Court said that its decision should not be regarded as precedent reveals clearly what was going on:  they wanted Bush, they ignored the Constitution to pick Bush, and that the decision was blatantly political, not judicial.  Yes, Bush vs. Gore ranks with Dred Scott, Plessy vs. Fergusion, and Korematsu as shameful monuments to  absurd legal reasoning and partisan politics disguised as judgement.  It was a disgrace then, its a disgrace now, and Justice O'Connor should have the decency to finally admit it.

I have often wondered if the Supreme Court might have decided Bush v. Gore by declaring that Florida's vote was so unclear that its electoral votes should not count one way or the other. That would have meant that neither Bush nor Gore would have received the necessary number of Electoral College votes to be elected, which would have thrown the election into Congress.

The House, given its political makeup at the time, would have elected Bush as president, while the Senate would have elected Lieberman as vice president. Same president, different vice president. Would that have made any difference from what actually happened?

Well, if Vice President Cheney was as influential as some would allege, it might have made a big difference ( Lieberman himself has been kind of hawkish, but perhaps more prudently so). A "split" executive branch might have helped promote more bi-partisanship.

But of course this is mere speculation, along the same lines as discussing what difference it might have made had Lincoln not been assassinated, or if the attempt to assassinate FDR before he was even inaugurated had been successful.

Republicans are always going to believe that it was an issue of following the rules to the letter of the law, while Democrats are always going to believe that it was a matter of the Supreme Court nullifying the will of the people.  The point is that we'll never know for sure who would have won Florida, and the Presidency, if all votes had been allowed to be counted.  There are provisions in the Constitution that allow for these issues to be played out and resolved in Congress by the peoples' representatives instead of being usurped by 9 unelected judges.  It seems to me that the Supreme Court could just as easily have said that if Florida's electoral process was so flawed, Florida would lose its votes in the Electoral College.  If that had happened, you can bet that Florida's next national election would have been the model of efficiency and transparency.

The different counties were using different standards, so the decentralized administration of elections (both within a state and between states) violates the Due Process Clause. Florida's violations seem to be worse than most. The Florida Supreme Court was not doing anything new.

Intentionally or not, Florida had developed an election system in which close and contested elections would be decided by political wrangling and rule-bending. The Supreme Court decided to contest some of this wrangling while leaving the rest alone.

As I remember, the Dems had Christopher and were being gentlemanly about the struggle, and the Republicans were going all-out to win. The Republicans were rewarded for their strategy and have continued it to this day. We could picture a Chalk Circle with Dems and Reps pulling on the infant Florida election. The wise judge would give the child to the mother who would or could not risk dislocating a shoulder with pulling. The Supremes gave the child to the mother who pulled harder, even though that mother's willingness to do that did not bode well for the child's welfare.

We got tax cuts designed to give the finger to Congressional rules designed to protect balanced budgets. We got a sales pitch for an unnecessary war that inevitably led to an occupation, which was completely botched. The sales pitch for our Iraq policy worked well enough here, but strangely not in Iraq.

You seem to forget that two of the seven Justices, Breyer and Souter, dissented from the other five in the result. While they both agreed that using different standards was a violation of the Due Process Clause, they also wrote that the majority's ruling to stop the recount would itself violate the Due Process Clause. After the first SCOTUS decision in the case, the Florida Supreme Court ruled that all votes in the state should be recounted., rather than just those in the four counties in question in the first decision. The issue in the second case was whether the recount of the complete state should be continued. Breyer and Souter both argued that it should continue.

Whatever the "nuance" inferred from Justice O'Connor's remarks, it is imperative to remember that 7 Justices agreed that the Florida Supreme Court's decision violated the Due Process Clause by using different standards for discerning voter "intent" in different counties.  It seems that everyone who has convinced themselves of a Republican conspiracy underlying the opinion omits that uncontroverted and indisputable fact.

How the devil did the public accept the NRA's twisted interpretation of the second amendment as fact? If you won't submit to militia regulation, you are an outlaw with a gun.

No one is suggesting you don't have a right to protect yourself, even with a gun. What we are saying is, that when your right bumps up against my right to live safe from mass murder, compromise is necessary.  That's the essence of the democracy you cherish.   To date, your side has conceded nothing to accomodate my rights and we live in a society where highly lethal force is too easily available.  If you truly want democracy, respect my rights and compromise.

If  our debate on our Second Amendment depended on statistics or opinion polls these past months of awful gun violence  there would be no Second Amendment. And there might be no democracy or Bill of Rights either. While we know that our government ought to have  the duty and  the power to protect us from every threat to our lives except those of our imagination, by what logic, law or sense does our government  have the right to prevent individual citizens from defending themselves at times when our government cannot protect us and we must take up arms to protect ourselves? Does our government have the right to prevent us from defending ourselves because it deems our right to own firearms for self-defense no longer a recognizable human right ?

There is no constitutionally protected right to own a gun. There is a right to bear arms as part of a regulated militia (e.g. police or army). This right orginated (almost word for word) from the English Bill of Rights of 1689. That right arose due to some groups being prohibited (on the basis of religion primarily) from joining the army and subsequent repression of those groups by the army. In effect, the right to bears arms is a right to serve one's country. The right was never associated with firearms or guns specifically.

This is reflected in many court judgements over many decades on the nature of the 2nd amendment. In a complete break from precedent, in 2008 the supreme court came up with a completely new interpretation that the right was related to gun ownership. This had never been its prior interpretation and the text of the new decision explicitly contradicts the wording of the amendment by saying the right to bear is in fact not related to militia at all. Of course the NRA had been pushing this interpretation for a long time. This new precedent is false and dangerous and should be overturned in favour of the long standing meaning of the 2nd amendment.

Agree with you that health care should be divorced from employment -- or at least favorable tax treatment should be eliminated or equalized.

I believe all members of Congress should be electing coverage under the ACA, although I don't have a problem with letting them have the same dollar amount of subsidy they currently get as federal employees under their FEBP. (I would object to a percentage, because comparable plans under ACA are likely to be much more expensive, & Congress otherwise not going to feel the pain constituents feel.)

Until I reached 65 & qualified for Medicare last year, I paid for an individual Blue Cross contract. In my last month, April 2012, my monthly premium was over $1700 for one person (over $20,000 a year). This was a standard contract with an out of network option that is similar, I believe, to the national Blue Cross plan that is so popular with members of Congress. New York is a guaranteed issue state, all comers required to be accepted,with standardized comprehensive plan provisions, & that is apparently why premiums were so high (and premiums were the same for everyone under a particular plan, old or young, sick or healthy). And because of different tax treatment of individual & employer plans, I couldn't deduct all my premiums.

For family of four, I believe Blue Cross charged somewhere in the neighborhood of $50,000 - $60,000 a year.

I am going to be fascinated to see what the charge for this plan is under the ACA.

Mulligan thinks he's smart but shows his ignorance. Health care under the ACA is subsidized for those not making enough to afford the full premium. A person of means does not get subsidized health care. The subsidies decrease as income rises.

People of little means or those that are on welfare/do not work already have 100% subsidized health care. It's called Medicaid.

The U.S. should divorce health care from employment. It would drastically reduce the cost of goods. GM once said they need to add $1500 per car to pay for insurance costs and this was a decade ago. Why would businesses want the burden to providing health insurance?

I know that many companies are dropping coverage or greatly increasing what an employee pays for their coverage. Because of this we're going to need the ACA more and more.
